reviewText: "The Underworld Story" concerns a yellow journalist who publishes an exposé that results in a gangland killing.Mike Reese (Duryea) is blacklisted for this and his supposed connection to a mob boss. When he can't find another job Reese buys a half-interest in a small New England paper by getting the cash from gambling kingpin Carl Durham (da Silva)-- the very man he was wrongly accused of associating with. Reese then tries to profit from the murder of a newpaper magnate's daughter.As of 2/09, "Underworld Story" was not available on DVD.Also recommended:Richard Widmark plays one of his "patented" gangster types in the shadowy true crime drama, THE STREET WITH NO NAME (1950).  (VHS edition)  (DVD edition)Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 viewer poll rating found at a film resource website.(6.9) The Underworld Story (1950) - Dan Duryea/Herbert Marshall/Gale Storm/Howard Da Silva/Michael O'Shea/Alan Hale Jr. (uncredited: Ned Glass)
Title: The Underworld Story

reviewText: The reason I got this film was solely to watch the work of its director, Cy Endfield, and I was not disappointed. Endfield's early work is very difficult to find. Having recently seen two of his best, TRY AND GET ME and HELL DRIVERS, at a film festival, I've become a fan. (I'm hoping those two movies are made available to the public soon as they are extraordinarily good.) While this film does not quite measure up to those titles, THE UNDERWORLD STORY is beautifully crafted and has one more indelible performance by the great noir character actor, Dan Duryea.
Title: The Underworld Story

reviewText: This DVD features one of the best restorations of a B&W film that we've ever seen (and we've seen a lot!). It is so clear and sharp and the audio matches. A powerful performances by Dan Duryea and some beautiful cinematography add to this really good movie. This is one of the nicest, quality DVDs we've come across.
summary: One of the best restorations of a B&W film!
Title: The Underworld Story

reviewText: The story concerns a wealthy newspaper man yielding to corruption to save face and protect his son.  Great performances through out this noir gem.
summary: A nugget from the Golden Age
Title: The Underworld Story

reviewText: THE UNDERWORLD STORY(1950) Directed by Cy Endfield. Script by Henry Blankfort.Starring Dan Duryea, Herbert Marshall, Gale Storm, Howard Da Silva, Michael O'Shea, Melville Cooper, Frieda Inescort, Roland Winters, Alan Hale Jr, Ned Glass and Edward Van Sloan as the Minister.After a sleazy reporter is made the scapegoat for something his newspaper gleefully approved of, he is blacklisted by the media and has to leave town---possibly Boston. Scrambling to a small town newspaper job, he luckily stumbles across the murder of the daughter in law of a major media mogul. When a young Black Woman is accused of the crime, the reporter sees this as his path back to the big time and quickly makes it a civil rights issue---concerned citizen's group and all.Yet the reporter does not quite know what he is getting into as the mogul is hiding a terrible secret and is willing to use his media power to see that the girl is convicted, the reporter ostracized and eventually a mob boss willing to do people favors becomes involved.A prime example of how the Production Code and Joseph Breen were the defenders of Art and not......as the propaganda tells us forever and ever--its enemy.  Here is a film that the history tells us was an effort by three Communists(Endfield, Blankfort and Da Silva) to create some nice commie prop attacking HUAC, anti-communist newspapers and the United States as being a seething caldron of racism. And certainly bits and pieces of that intent can still just be gleaned. The word Witchunt is used constantly though there is nothing of the kind going on. The black girl--negro or not--is one of those falsely accused people who do silly things like immediately putting their finger prints on knives sticking out of people's back. Here pawning the jewels of the victim right after her death. Black or not, she looks guilty as sin and she still gets the immediate support of her neighbors. The mogul is coded in a brief moment as being supposedly Anti-Union. But that is about it.Obviously Joe Breen stood athwart of history and yelled "Hold it Comrades!!"And the film was saved from being a piece of offensive ephemeral propaganda for genocidal monsters and instead became something that......like all true art---speaks to 2008 as well as 1950.Instead of commie prop, the film becomes a 50s version of FIVE STAR FINAL--to wit a searing condemnation of an unregulated media. It is not the gangster or the sleazy reporter or the murder or the Black Girl that is the problem here but a runaway media that does as it pleases when it pleases without any checks or balances. Today the usual suspects might try and wiggle out of it by saying "Oh just like Fox News and Rupert Murdock!" But the film easily allows the rejoinder of "Oh just like the Liberal Media and CNN!!" There is even a moment where because a newspaper revealed a secret ala the New York Times revealing American secret operations against Al Queda that someone is killed and the War on Crime delivered a setback.No. This film speaks to the concept and not any particular side. An unregulated Media can kill.The acting is superb especially Duryea as the reporter and Da Silva as the gangster. Marshall is very sympathetic in what could be played as a cardboard cut out villain------and probably would have been if the three comrades had their way. Former Charlie Chan Roland Winters as a for the buck lawyer is very good and completely unrecognizable as the once Oriental sleuth. And yes that is dear old Edward Van Sloan is a showy part as the Minister at the burial still plugging away nearly two decades after DRACULA.The direction is very good as is the black and white photography.A text book example of a film that is far better than it should have been thanks not to its Machiavellian makers but bad old Joe Breen and the Code.Recommended.
summary: There are two underworlds here.  Before the camera and behind the camera
Title: The Underworld Story
